FROM A LONDON PAPER OF AUGUST 8. 1927.


At the present assizes for Worcester, certain
parties were indicted for stealing flUo ducks; but
as it came out in evidence that they Killed the two
ducks before they stole them. Mr. Justice Iiltedae
charged the jury to find them not guilty. on the
ground that in legal construction the words 9 two
ducks'' must be taken to mean 6 two Ere ducks :"
whereas. it was proved that these ducks were deai:
and the parties we're found not guilty accordingly.
query: is not duck duck ? And if not. wnat
is It'll Would the thieves who stole the ducks have
been not guilty Of stealing the ducks, surprising they
had only hay killed the ducks before they stole
them


A notorious gang of robbers, on the Windsor
road. escaped at the Quarter sessions. because the
drawing up of the indictment had described gown
and petlcoat as the property OF woman instead OF
man this said woman happening to be married,
the learned chairman held that it legally belonged to
the husband, and on this plea the whole gang were
acquitted, much to the annoyance pf worthy ma
gistrate who declared that he had heard of wife
wearing the breeches, but never before OF husband
wearing the pettcoat. At the same sessions an in
diyldua. tried on an indictment for sheep stealing.
seemed i'll fair way to escape, by his legal defender
proving that the animal was not leeally sheep, in
consequence of not being come Of age and the mat
ter was put aside to be grayey argued at future
period. Nothing could exceed the astonishment of





vowed he would call pig, and try what the effect
of that would be.


WHO shall decide when doctors disagree ~
Judge Best's charge in favor Of pugilism, will be
found under that head in another place. At the
same point of time Judge Garrow was making the
following charge against it at Bedford. He said If
quarrel is treasured up, and time be taken to ar
range the meeting and one of the party fails, the
the offence amounts TO murder, and principal Sc
conds, and BY ISLANDERS were all guilty. He called
on the Grand Jury to put stop to the practice OF
prize fights, which he regretted to say, had been
patlonized by men Of rank, who sported their soy-
ereigns on the life or death of fellow creature.


John Maule, the prisoner tried at Salisbury, was
indict I'd for having, the 18th of Jane last, Killed
one Thomas Strange. by upsetting cuach on which
the said I. Strange was passenger. Inc second
count described the coach as having been drawn tty
fsco geldngs and tsco mares One objection to the
Indictment, namely, that it did not state the acc-
dent to have occurred on the Kings highway, or IN
public road and all the precedents showed that such
an averment was necessary, was over-rulea ny the
chief Justice who observed, that he had little doubt
. the precedents would furnish instances OF nom
sense of all sorts.'' But it was then oblected-lt
was alleged that the coach was drawn by two mares
and two geldings, which allegation had not been
supported by proof This was humping objection
two mares and two gednss stated in the ndlct-
nlent, and no one to prove the avsrment The
UNCERTAINTY OF THE LAW.

THE DELAJY.aRE JOURNAL is pub
tshed on Tuesdays and Fridays. at four dollars
per aanum; tsoo dollars every sir months IA ad-
DunCe.


advertisements inserted on the ns1taL terms
Vi: One dollar for .fom insertions Of sicteen
lines. and oia proportion for erery number Of
additional lines and insertions.
COMlggTCNS.

upon female beauty, and on the children Of Eu-
ropean parents. 1t is rare to see foreign families
preserve theirs; they generally die at an early age;
and this, too, IS one of the why the Mame-
ukes OF Egypt never have any posterity, but al
ways recruited by the purchase Of young boys, gen.
orally brought from Circassia, and the provinces
bordering on the black Sea, and the Ural Mountains


The mortality of children in Egypt is excessive
it is chiefly caused by that unhappy fatasm which
prevents the natives from providing against the dis
ease TO which that age is subject The smallpox a.
lone carries Oft one third of the children. The
Pacha, Notwithstanding all his endeavors to intro
duce vaccination. has been able to attain his object
but lmperectiy; and, if we add to the ravages of
the small pox, those of the plague and malignant
fevers we Shall to wonder that this fertile
country is not entirely changed into desert Cairo
In the times of the Caiphs, still had population Of
nearly one million, which is now reduced to about
one-third.


1t is melancholy to see how all the measures Of
an enlightened Government are constantly counter
acted IN Egypt, by the religious and fanatic ideas of
the inhabitants However, the Pacha has already
made gigantic strides and. if his successors should
be wise enough to proceed in the same course, this
fertile land would. doubtless afford in future ages
the appearance of a new creation.


Refreshments were brought in on a small table OF
cedar, very low, ornanented with a pretty Mosaic
Oh IVORY ana nother o1-pear. Inc collauon CON-
sisted of confectionery, cakes made of honey and
fruits. and sherbet. Meantime, some slaves burnt


incense in silver censers, and frequently sprnkled
Gs with rose water. Two others placed themselves
at my side and every time that | either ate OF
drank any thing, were ready to hold under my lips
a napkin OF a course quality, yet embroidered with
gold. Others, provided with fans, drove away the
swarms Of insects which the pastry and fruit had
attracted around lis. In short, each seemed to have
a particular function to perform. When the repast
was ended they wished me to pass the night with


hem, and TO take the bath; but having already ac-
guan'ed myself with this kind Of amusement al
Caro-. | declined their polite invitation.


fThe present Pacha, Mahomet Ali, has two legi
innate wives, one Of whom resides at Cairo, and thu
| other at Alexandria. The number of his concubine


is immense there are above 200 in his harem at AL
| eyandria

| "When at Cairo, had been several times soIi- |
cited to visit the harem of the PacAa, favor which
is generally not granted to strangers. 1t is GUS
tonary in the East to make reciprocal presents in
such interviews. Not beng able 70 procure in this I
city any productions of Europe. worthy Of being Of
fered to these tar odalisques of such high rank,
was for long time Obliged to RESTRAIN my curiosity,
aud renounce this visit.


| At Danletta, however, where fresh occasion |
presented itself OF visiting the harem of the Aga,
Governor of the Provinces, and where should not
be obliged to present such magnificent gifts, re-
solved to make myself acquainted with an abode |
which contained 50 many things contrary to the
taste, the ideas, aud manners, of Europe. The !
harem of the Aga situated nearly opposite to
the residence of Mr.. Faker. the other bank Of the
Nile in garden. i'll the Turkish stile, that is to say
a piece Of ground without trees. | was accompani
ed by the lady Of the Portuguese physician, who un
derstood little Italian and Arabic, and VINO was
to act as interpreter When we arrived at the build
ing we were received by black eunuch richly
dressed, who invited US to go into very cool apait
nent, with lattced windows, and no furniture ~
cept very broad and low divan. He LETT u. to an
nounce us to his mistress soon after saw INC
two wives OF the Aga, accompanied BY tW OF MS
daughters, one OF whom was yet child and the 9th
er married to OF the superior officers in the
my, and about twenty young slaves The TWO la
dies, as well as the daughters of the Aga, seated
themselves next to me while the slaves ranged them
selves in half circle before U.S. with their
sed their breast, and preserving respectful
, lence. As all these women spoke only turkish, we
needed second interpreter, who, in her turn. I'M
derstood only Turkish and Arabic, so that what
said in Italian had to be translated into Arabic, and
the Arabic into Turkish; thus, to understand each
other, we had need of three languages and two inter
prefers.


ltmay readily be supposed that the conversation
could not go on uently, as we depended on the good
will and talents OF our interpreters in fact, qut pro
. que resulting from the bad TRANSACTIONS of our qnes
:. lions and answers, were truly comic, and created
much gacty, that loud and repeated bursts of laugh
ter established good understanding between
us. The oldest OF the consorts OF the Aga, howev-
er, maintained dignlEed gravity, while the other,
who was much younger, and OF an animated and in
terestng countenance, repeated with extreme volu-
by the most insignificant questions, and did not fail


to examine the whole arrangement Of my toilette.
They asked me many questions respecting the wo-
inen i'll my country or Europe, believe they
entertained very vague notions Of and when |


told them that our husbands had but wife, and
no slaves, they looked at another, undctermin-
ed whether to applaud or to laugh at this custom


The eldest daughter of the Aga was young per-


son OF the most beautiful and pleasing countenance.


She did not enjoy good health. Her extreme pale
ness rendered her really interesting in my eyes :
she resembled lilly langushing, and wthered by





cherish e, from the idea that |, perhaps, possessed


the skill to her and arnastly cntreated me to


prescribe some remedy. There is something sim
er guar in the conviction generally entertained by the


Orientals, that all Europeans, without distinction,


have knowledge Of medicine and necromancy, arts


commonly coniounded with one another. 1t several
3 times happened to us in Upper Egypt, to be called


to the assistance of persons actually dying or ia so


desperate state, that nothing less than conjurer


would have been required TO preserve their lives.


Without being distinguished disciple OF Hippo


crates. it is easy to acquire the reputation OF an
&c able physician and the really skful medical man
int who accompanied us during our tour in Upper Egypt


accustomed, such occasions, that is, when the


case was not desperate in imitation OF the celebra-


ted Sangrada, OF happy memory to administer On


y the most simple remedies which never failed to


produce prompt and marvellous effect SO much


influence has the imagination Of these children Of


nature their cure. But to return to my fair oda-


lsques


They were nearly all natives of Syria Circassla,


and Georgia. and had thus leisure to survey these
IN. beauties who enjoy much celebrity. They IN
. doubtedly merit their reputation can, however,


tell my fair country women, to comfort them. and to
al do justice to TRUTH that Europe certainly can boast
~ of beauties equal to those OF the East Those whom
~ had now the pleasure of seeing, had the most agree
' able countenances and delicate and regular eatures


but what most attracted my admiration, was their


hair, which fell in waving and natural curs down to


their waist. They had each preserved their ma
y onal costume, which agreeably varied this pretty
= parterre nor had they adopted the tresses OF the
= Egyptian women, which rather dishgure than I'M
., prove the figure They had exqusitey beautiful
~ teeth but the cearness and bloom OF youth were
: banished from their complexion they all had a
n anguid air. and did not find among them that en-
&C. bonpoiat which had expected to meet. Perhaps
!. their sedentary mode of le and the destructive eli

publishing by subscription "1he Works ofGEORGE
avith Historical Notes and Ntustra-
tions.'' This work will be comprised i'll no less
than eight, nor more than twelve large octave voi-
umes. A specimen Of the manner IN which 1t IS to
be executed, as it regards type and paper accompa-
MES the proposals 1t is extremely elegant, highly
creditabe 10 the press from which it proceeds, and
worthy off the work preparing for publication.


II is stated that g the most valuable parts OF the
entire collection left by Gen. Washington at Mount
Vernon, both of public and private nature are to
be prepared and published according to the follows
ing method


partl. Letters and other Papers relating to Washs
ngtons early military in the French War
and as commander Of the Virginia Forces.


Part IL. Letters and other Papers relating to the
American Revolution.


Iii. Private Correspondence on Public Affairs.


w. Messages and Addresses.


V. Miscellaneous Private Papers.


vi. Agricultural Papers"


1t is very apparent from this statement, that this
work will contain general, and indeed d very exs
tenslve view of the life, actions, principles, and
character of the iustrious author. This alone
would secure it degree of popularity, which cant
scarcely be expected to meet with rival pubcas
ton in this respect.


George Washington passed through life full
of incidents life Of activity OF responsibility, OF





of fearful dangers without stain. History scasce1
y furnishes an instance of purer morals, of more
disinerested and elevated patriotism, or OF NOR:
unblemshed conduct i'll the most trying scenes q
life than his. As military Chlei, he mas rarely
been surpassed as a statesman, lew have peen
more distinguished none more useiui OF ertuo9ss
We consider it of great importance to hi5 nemor,
as we'll as to the country, and the world, that he
should be thoroughly and perfectly known Pm
cause satisfied that h6 was as grcut at hoac,
in the secluded retirement and pursuits Of pflVat.
and domestic life, as he in the field and in a
cabinet. General Washington was made great
nlan-he ~as an honor 10 his name. to his ccunrys
and to the world.--Very few such men nave passed
over the stage of life. crown and throne wond
have added nothing to the spleEdop OF his characs
ter; and 1t is fit that the foundation of hls greatreaa
should be fairly exhibited to the view Of rilatkud
in order that the envy and lll-nalure-he mearresa
and deprayy Of party spirit, which once yainy ens
deavored to ociact from his character, and under
value his services, may b. more thoroughly expos4
ed, anil more correctly estlmateds


We have no doubt this work will meet with the
most liberal encouragement. Every man that truly
reyeres the AUTHOR, and feels as grateful as hc
ought for the benefits he has conferred on hls coun
try will avail himself Of the opportunity to procure
the present publication.


AonrtuETURAL. valuable and handsome ocfas
70 volume. entitled "Hlnts for Anerican Hnsbinds
man, has Just been issued by order of the Direcora
of the Pennsylvania Agricultural Society. 1t cons
ssts chiefly OF communications, OF "A practical na4
ture, to that society; aud its worth Is ehhanced BY
some very neat and appropriate ensraymgs. We
scarcely need to mention that considerable and ess
Unable portion Of its contents is from ,he pen os
tJonn Hare Powell. Esq. OF our city, who we pre-;
sume, has edited the work, and to whon Anieticait
agriculture, in the most comprehensive senses Is S6
largely indebted His intelligence zeal and success
in the various departments of husbandry. must ses
cure for him the regard and gratitude. not only 1T
actual farmers but of all patriotic citizens who uns
derstand the public usefulness Of agricultural pGra
suits. The main topics treated of in this Volt The
are-Neat Cattle Sheep; Crops and Mannfssa
Substitutes for Hay Grass Lands Art Of Brse,
ding, and Root Crops. We have marked few o
the napers for the purpose of copying them hsreat
ter into our first page If we should find the opportua
nifty of 50 doing they would be interesting to all
general readers. HE whole will no doubts be eiis
long in the hands of most of the american country
gentlemen. Some Of the original tommuncatohs
are from England; others from different States Of
our Union. National Gazette.
| american Laee.-Ihe attempts to manufacture
Lace in this country to any extent, although Of tho
most recent origin, have nevertheless been crowned
with a success which promises to render Us, at NO
distant period, entirely independent of foreiah
countries for the supply Of this costly article of dress
Several lace factories have lateysprung upin Rhode
Island, the principal of which is at Newport II
employs 600 persons, principally females, who man.
ufacture wells, caps pelerlnes, and ndeed faces OF
all descriptions. The taste and ingenuity display
ed in the fabrication Of these articles are highly
spoken Of.

country is not entirely changed into desert Cairo
In the times of the Caiphs, still had population Of
nearly one million, which is now reduced to about
one-third.


1t is melancholy to see how all the measures Of
an enlightened Government are constantly counter
acted IN Egypt, by the religious and fanatic ideas of
the inhabitants However, the Pacha has already
made gigantic strides and. if his successors should
be wise enough to proceed in the same course, this
fertile land would. doubtless afford in future ages
the appearance of a new creation.


Refreshments were brought in on a small table OF
cedar, very low, ornanented with a pretty Mosaic
Oh IVORY ana nother o1-pear. Inc collauon CON-
sisted of confectionery, cakes made of honey and
fruits. and sherbet. Meantime, some slaves burnt


incense in silver censers, and frequently sprnkled
Gs with rose water. Two others placed themselves
at my side and every time that | either ate OF
drank any thing, were ready to hold under my lips
a napkin OF a course quality, yet embroidered with
gold. Others, provided with fans, drove away the
swarms Of insects which the pastry and fruit had
attracted around lis. In short, each seemed to have
a particular function to perform. When the repast
was ended they wished me to pass the night with


hem, and TO take the bath; but having already ac-
guan'ed myself with this kind Of amusement al
Caro-. | declined their polite invitation.


fThe present Pacha, Mahomet Ali, has two legi
innate wives, one Of whom resides at Cairo, and thu
| other at Alexandria. The number of his concubine


is immense there are above 200 in his harem at AL
| eyandria

| "When at Cairo, had been several times soIi- |
cited to visit the harem of the PacAa, favor which
is generally not granted to strangers. 1t is GUS
tonary in the East to make reciprocal presents in
such interviews. Not beng able 70 procure in this I
city any productions of Europe. worthy Of being Of
fered to these tar odalisques of such high rank,
was for long time Obliged to RESTRAIN my curiosity,
aud renounce this visit.


| At Danletta, however, where fresh occasion |
presented itself OF visiting the harem of the Aga,
Governor of the Provinces, and where should not
be obliged to present such magnificent gifts, re-
solved to make myself acquainted with an abode |
which contained 50 many things contrary to the
taste, the ideas, aud manners, of Europe. The !
harem of the Aga situated nearly opposite to
the residence of Mr.. Faker. the other bank Of the
Nile in garden. i'll the Turkish stile, that is to say
a piece Of ground without trees. | was accompani
ed by the lady Of the Portuguese physician, who un
derstood little Italian and Arabic, and VINO was
to act as interpreter When we arrived at the build
ing we were received by black eunuch richly
dressed, who invited US to go into very cool apait
nent, with lattced windows, and no furniture ~
cept very broad and low divan. He LETT u. to an
nounce us to his mistress soon after saw INC
two wives OF the Aga, accompanied BY tW OF MS
daughters, one OF whom was yet child and the 9th
er married to OF the superior officers in the
my, and about twenty young slaves The TWO la
dies, as well as the daughters of the Aga, seated
themselves next to me while the slaves ranged them
selves in half circle before U.S. with their
sed their breast, and preserving respectful
, lence. As all these women spoke only turkish, we
needed second interpreter, who, in her turn. I'M
derstood only Turkish and Arabic, so that what
said in Italian had to be translated into Arabic, and
the Arabic into Turkish; thus, to understand each
other, we had need of three languages and two inter
prefers.


ltmay readily be supposed that the conversation
could not go on uently, as we depended on the good
will and talents OF our interpreters in fact, qut pro
. que resulting from the bad TRANSACTIONS of our qnes
:. lions and answers, were truly comic, and created
much gacty, that loud and repeated bursts of laugh
ter established good understanding between
us. The oldest OF the consorts OF the Aga, howev-
er, maintained dignlEed gravity, while the other,
who was much younger, and OF an animated and in
terestng countenance, repeated with extreme volu-
by the most insignificant questions, and did not fail


to examine the whole arrangement Of my toilette.
They asked me many questions respecting the wo-
inen i'll my country or Europe, believe they
entertained very vague notions Of and when |


told them that our husbands had but wife, and
no slaves, they looked at another, undctermin-
ed whether to applaud or to laugh at this custom


The eldest daughter of the Aga was young per-


son OF the most beautiful and pleasing countenance.


She did not enjoy good health. Her extreme pale
ness rendered her really interesting in my eyes :
she resembled lilly langushing, and wthered by





cherish e, from the idea that |, perhaps, possessed


the skill to her and arnastly cntreated me to


prescribe some remedy. There is something sim
er guar in the conviction generally entertained by the


Orientals, that all Europeans, without distinction,


have knowledge Of medicine and necromancy, arts


commonly coniounded with one another. 1t several
3 times happened to us in Upper Egypt, to be called


to the assistance of persons actually dying or ia so


desperate state, that nothing less than conjurer


would have been required TO preserve their lives.


Without being distinguished disciple OF Hippo


crates. it is easy to acquire the reputation OF an
&c able physician and the really skful medical man
int who accompanied us during our tour in Upper Egypt


accustomed, such occasions, that is, when the


case was not desperate in imitation OF the celebra-


ted Sangrada, OF happy memory to administer On


y the most simple remedies which never failed to


produce prompt and marvellous effect SO much


influence has the imagination Of these children Of


nature their cure. But to return to my fair oda-


lsques


They were nearly all natives of Syria Circassla,


and Georgia. and had thus leisure to survey these
IN. beauties who enjoy much celebrity. They IN
. doubtedly merit their reputation can, however,


tell my fair country women, to comfort them. and to
al do justice to TRUTH that Europe certainly can boast
~ of beauties equal to those OF the East Those whom
~ had now the pleasure of seeing, had the most agree
' able countenances and delicate and regular eatures


but what most attracted my admiration, was their


hair, which fell in waving and natural curs down to


their waist. They had each preserved their ma
y onal costume, which agreeably varied this pretty
= parterre nor had they adopted the tresses OF the
= Egyptian women, which rather dishgure than I'M
., prove the figure They had exqusitey beautiful
~ teeth but the cearness and bloom OF youth were
: banished from their complexion they all had a
n anguid air. and did not find among them that en-
&C. bonpoiat which had expected to meet. Perhaps
!. their sedentary mode of le and the destructive eli

LIFE Of WASHINGTON.
full articles.article:
publishing by subscription "1he Works ofGEORGE
avith Historical Notes and Ntustra-
tions.'' This work will be comprised i'll no less
than eight, nor more than twelve large octave voi-
umes. A specimen Of the manner IN which 1t IS to
be executed, as it regards type and paper accompa-
MES the proposals 1t is extremely elegant, highly
creditabe 10 the press from which it proceeds, and
worthy off the work preparing for publication.


II is stated that g the most valuable parts OF the
entire collection left by Gen. Washington at Mount
Vernon, both of public and private nature are to
be prepared and published according to the follows
ing method


partl. Letters and other Papers relating to Washs
ngtons early military in the French War
and as commander Of the Virginia Forces.


Part IL. Letters and other Papers relating to the
American Revolution.


Iii. Private Correspondence on Public Affairs.


w. Messages and Addresses.


V. Miscellaneous Private Papers.


vi. Agricultural Papers"


1t is very apparent from this statement, that this
work will contain general, and indeed d very exs
tenslve view of the life, actions, principles, and
character of the iustrious author. This alone
would secure it degree of popularity, which cant
scarcely be expected to meet with rival pubcas
ton in this respect.


George Washington passed through life full
of incidents life Of activity OF responsibility, OF





of fearful dangers without stain. History scasce1
y furnishes an instance of purer morals, of more
disinerested and elevated patriotism, or OF NOR:
unblemshed conduct i'll the most trying scenes q
life than his. As military Chlei, he mas rarely
been surpassed as a statesman, lew have peen
more distinguished none more useiui OF ertuo9ss
We consider it of great importance to hi5 nemor,
as we'll as to the country, and the world, that he
should be thoroughly and perfectly known Pm
cause satisfied that h6 was as grcut at hoac,
in the secluded retirement and pursuits Of pflVat.
and domestic life, as he in the field and in a
cabinet. General Washington was made great
nlan-he ~as an honor 10 his name. to his ccunrys
and to the world.--Very few such men nave passed
over the stage of life. crown and throne wond
have added nothing to the spleEdop OF his characs
ter; and 1t is fit that the foundation of hls greatreaa
should be fairly exhibited to the view Of rilatkud
in order that the envy and lll-nalure-he mearresa
and deprayy Of party spirit, which once yainy ens
deavored to ociact from his character, and under
value his services, may b. more thoroughly expos4
ed, anil more correctly estlmateds


We have no doubt this work will meet with the
most liberal encouragement. Every man that truly
reyeres the AUTHOR, and feels as grateful as hc
ought for the benefits he has conferred on hls coun
try will avail himself Of the opportunity to procure
the present publication.


AonrtuETURAL. valuable and handsome ocfas
70 volume. entitled "Hlnts for Anerican Hnsbinds
man, has Just been issued by order of the Direcora
of the Pennsylvania Agricultural Society. 1t cons
ssts chiefly OF communications, OF "A practical na4
ture, to that society; aud its worth Is ehhanced BY
some very neat and appropriate ensraymgs. We
scarcely need to mention that considerable and ess
Unable portion Of its contents is from ,he pen os
tJonn Hare Powell. Esq. OF our city, who we pre-;
sume, has edited the work, and to whon Anieticait
agriculture, in the most comprehensive senses Is S6
largely indebted His intelligence zeal and success
in the various departments of husbandry. must ses
cure for him the regard and gratitude. not only 1T
actual farmers but of all patriotic citizens who uns
derstand the public usefulness Of agricultural pGra
suits. The main topics treated of in this Volt The
are-Neat Cattle Sheep; Crops and Mannfssa
Substitutes for Hay Grass Lands Art Of Brse,
ding, and Root Crops. We have marked few o
the napers for the purpose of copying them hsreat
ter into our first page If we should find the opportua
nifty of 50 doing they would be interesting to all
general readers. HE whole will no doubts be eiis
long in the hands of most of the american country
gentlemen. Some Of the original tommuncatohs
are from England; others from different States Of
our Union. National Gazette.
| american Laee.-Ihe attempts to manufacture
Lace in this country to any extent, although Of tho
most recent origin, have nevertheless been crowned
with a success which promises to render Us, at NO
distant period, entirely independent of foreiah
countries for the supply Of this costly article of dress
Several lace factories have lateysprung upin Rhode
Island, the principal of which is at Newport II
employs 600 persons, principally females, who man.
ufacture wells, caps pelerlnes, and ndeed faces OF
all descriptions. The taste and ingenuity display
ed in the fabrication Of these articles are highly
spoken Of.
